title: Altered quorum sensing and physiology of Staphylococcus aureus during spaceflight detected by multi-omics data analysis
background: Staphylococcus aureus is a significant human pathogen that colonizes approximately 30% of humans and poses health risks to astronauts during spaceflight missions. Previous studies have shown S. aureus can be recovered from astronauts at higher numbers post-flight, and staphylococci are predominant microbes aboard the ISS.
objective: To analyze the response of S. aureus to the spaceflight environment using multi-omics approaches to understand alterations in physiology and virulence potential.
methods: Multi-omics analysis of RNA-Seq, cellular proteomics, metabolomics, and secretomics data from the BRIC-23 spaceflight experiment comparing asynchronous ground control and spaceflight cultures grown for 48 hours at ISS ambient temperature (~22째C) using Biological Research in Canisters-Petri Dish Fixation Units.
results: Spaceflight cultures showed significant upregulation of Agr quorum sensing system (RNAIII upregulated 88-fold), increased expression of virulence factors (proteases, toxins, Type VII secretion system), altered metabolism (increased amino acid metabolism, TCA cycle, urease activity), and decreased glycolysis/fermentation. FLT cultures achieved higher cell densities with 30% less secreted protein concentration.
conclusion: S. aureus experiences increased quorum sensing and altered expression of virulence factors in response to the spaceflight environment that may impact its pathogenic potential for astronauts during long-duration missions.

core_problems: Astronaut health risks from opportunistic pathogens
Limited medical treatment capabilities in space
extracted_entities.confidence: Validated with multiple biological replicates and multiple omics approaches showing consistent patterns
gaps: Unknown if growth phase differences contributed to observations

learning_notes.note: The Agr quorum sensing system was dramatically upregulated in spaceflight, with RNAIII showing an 88-fold increase and agr operon genes showing approximately 14-fold increases, indicating enhanced cell-to-cell communication and potential virulence activation in the space environment.

Spaceflight cultures showed increased abundance of Agr-regulated virulence factors including proteases (SspA, SspB, ScpA), staphylococcal nuclease, phenol-soluble modulins, and Type VII secretion system components, suggesting enhanced pathogenic potential during spaceflight.

Metabolic alterations included increased amino acid metabolism, TCA cycle activity, and transport of non-preferred carbon sources, while glycolysis/fermentation and translation machinery were decreased, indicating a shift in energy metabolism under spaceflight conditions.

Despite higher cell densities in spaceflight cultures (based on CFU counts), the concentration of secreted proteins was approximately 30% lower, possibly due to increased protease activity degrading the exoproteome.

Urease activity was significantly upregulated with seven genes showing 4-5 fold increases, which may represent an adaptation to acid stress and alternative ATP production pathways through the arginine deiminase pathway.

The BRIC-23 experiment used asynchronous ground controls with identical hardware, timing, and temperature conditions, but was limited by analysis at a single time point (48 hours) and non-physiological temperature (22째C), affecting interpretation of results.

Multiple non-Agr regulated virulence factors were also upregulated, including Type VII-like Ess secretion system components and staphylococcal nuclease, suggesting spaceflight affects virulence through both Agr-dependent and independent mechanisms.
